before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"8islu","text":"This pipeline requires a Linux or Mac operating system (OS) to run FreeSurfer and MMVT. Our instructions here will be specific to Linux, but the same principles apply to a Mac OS. In general, the programs we use (MATLAB and FreeSurfer especially) have comprehensive installation and tutorials, but we will include bare-bones guides to get you started. Please look at Appendix I if you are unfamiliar with using the terminal. See the Appendix II-VII on instructions for checking that your system is correctly configured and installing FreeSurfer. Examples of the pipeline's output are in the Materials section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5v23b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8abnj","text":"Step 1 requires DICOM retrieval tool","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ceb4t","text":"Steps 2-4 require FreeSurfer","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dfk77","text":"Step 5-6 require iELVis, MATLAB, Fieldtrip, and our pipeline code on Github","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a1fl5","text":"Step 7 requires MMVT-lite","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"i4uo","text":"This pipeline involves taking pre- and post-operative images to localized and visualize electrode locations in the case of implanted intracranial electrodes, whether the electrodes penetrate the brain parenchyma (depth, stereoelectroencephalography, sEEG electrodes) or are on the surface of the cortex (strip or grid, electrocorticography, ECoG, electrodes). The pipeline uses a number of different packages in a modular approach that allows use of a subset or all parts of the pipeline depending on need.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Retrieving Images and Saving Files
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b983d","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"58b9t","text":"Retrieve Images","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"38n7c","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"2c8ef","text":"When retrieving imaging as DICOMs, you can download the entire imaging series or just the sequence of interest, whichever is easiest for your setup. If there is not a T1 MRI with high enough resolution, a T2/FLAIR image with good resolution can supplement (but not replace!) the bad T1 in the FreeSurfer reconstruction process (see Step 2.2).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fv2hj","text":"May require the installation of a DICOM viewer like Mango (see Materials)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Retrieving Images and Saving Files
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cnvq0","text":"Download pre-op MRI imaging. MRI requirement:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5a6mb","text":"T1 (MPRAGE, SPGR, Ax T1 NAV, ect.) with as many slices as possible, good resolution between grey and white matter, and ideally without contrast (Step 1.2, Panel A). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: FreeSurfer Output
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"16t0a","text":"FreeSurfer Output","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ks5d","text":"Once your imaging scans are selected, move the pre-op NifTI file into the folder required by FreeSurfer installation (usually somewhere like ~/home/freesurfer/subjects). During this step, you will open a terminal (right click and select “Open Terminal”) and run the commands which make all the 3D files, cortical parcellations, and subcortical segmentations of the input brain. From here on, any instance of “id##” is the name and number of the subject you are currently running through the pipeline. You must replace every “id##” with your subject name.","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":378,"length":175}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"co3ku","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6i5j2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2e9h6","text":"This step requires","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5pchm","text":"Skip this step if you require only the 2D visuals output. Skipping this step is not possible for grid and strips because a 3D model of the brain will be required to adjust the electrode locations in Snap_to_Grid.m.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

When working with Freeview, you will only be manipulating the volume which is highlighted at the top left of the screen (Step 3.3, Figure). This is the most hands-on and time-intensive step and will require patience and persistence until you become skilled at it.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4tg0q","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":82,"offset":56},{"key":1,"length":25,"offset":149}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2uto5","text":"There are automatic co-registration approaches (iELVis: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0165027017300365?via%3Dihub, LeadDBS: https://www.lead-dbs.org/, or","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"length":53,"offset":23}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7u0s5","text":"Freesurfer tkregister: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2733527/ for instance) which could also be used. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"9E201F68693A11ED86880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0165027017300365?via%3Dihub"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"1":{"data":{"guid":"ADB3A3DB693A11ED86880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.lead-dbs.org"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"2":{"data":{"guid":"04E83A27693B11ED86880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2733527"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

steps.section: Identifying RAS Coordinates
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5rt33","text":"Once all RAS coordinates for all electrodes have been located, check to ensure that the orientation of the coordinates is correct using this test: look at the RAS coordinates section in Freeview (Step 4.4 Figure, zoomed portion). The R, A, S numbers (the first, second and third numbers in the Freeview TkReg RAS row) should increase positively in the right, anterior, and superior directions, respectively. If they do not, you must account for this in coordinate transcription. There are 3 options for each of the coordinates, R, A, and S:\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f2bau","text":"All values are in the correct orientation. Nothing additional needs to be done once you write down the value from Freeview.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2lf6u","text":"Some of the values are switched (e.g., R may be in the S position). Test this by moving the cursor in each of the three directions and making sure the value in the correct spot changes in RAS instead of ARS or SAR. For example, moving the cursor towards the anterior of the image will result in the second value in the RAS field changing. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dggup","text":"Some of the values could be inverted. This means the RAS values are in the correct order, but they may be flipped. For example, if the R value decreases when you move the cursor to the right and increases when you move the cursor to the left, then R values are inverted.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32soq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"12ljj","text":"Just account for these changes in the final RAS excel sheet before moving forward. Multiply inverted columns by -1 or shift columns which were switched in the original Freeview.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6i0is","text":"Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes. If your subject has exclusively depths (sEEG), skip to next section)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":154}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7rm67","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"82v25","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7j863","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"33mo","text":"Snapping the electrode grid to the surface of the brain is necessary to account for brain movement or compression that occurs immediately after grid implantation. This brain shift can depend on the location and size of the grids used and can influence the location of the brain in the postoperative MRI or CT. Therefore, the surface of the cortex is different between the pre-operative scan used in the FreeSurfer pipeline and the post-operative scan. This difference must be accounted for by shifting the grid to the surface of the pre-op imaging, rather than relying solely on the post-op imaging.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8kfe5","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eo4kv","text":"This section requires downloading iELVis and the GitHub code (see Materials).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1ve8n","text":"You should create a directory in which you place each subject’s folder. We will call this the working directory (wd).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a1uuu","text":"Create an id## folder in the wd containing:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":10,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fl4h5","text":"RAS coordinates in an Excel spreadsheet","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f5ul6","text":"SurferOutput folder for the patient","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9ij5j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"87b5c","text":"For each patient, make a new copy of “idxx_Snap_to_Grid.m” from the Protocol_Snap_to_Grid.m code file located on the GitHub page. This isn't necessary, just a recommendation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":38,"length":4},{"style":"italic","offset":38,"length":19},{"style":"italic","offset":68,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9ki0s","text":"Change the Pt (line 10) and the reconPath (line 11) variables to be the patient's name and the path to your wd folder, respectively. steps.section: Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"attuk","text":"Next, you must create a variable which has each electrode’s RAS coordinates. Please look in the Protocol_Snap_to_Grid.m for an example of how this is done. You can partition them up as whole electrodes or break them down into strips. For example, if you have an 8x8 grid, we usually break it down into eight 1x8 strips. Each strip will usually be handled by the algorithm better than the whole grid, though you can experiment with keeping them whole. Start the counting of the RAS_coords at 1, as in this example, and not at 2, as in the RAS file itself.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":96,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mrpn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"krii","text":" steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6u47v","text":"Ensure the side variable (line ~40) at the top of the next section is set to the correct hemisphere (“l” for left, and “r” for right). steps.section: Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"p3j2","text":"When you run this algorithm for each electrode RAS variable you made, you will see a 3D projection of the electrodes as they snap themselves to the brain’s surface. You should watch each of these carefully as they will tell you if the algorithm is functioning as desired. The electrode contact points should be moving along a relatively straight line to the brain’s surface (FIG ii). They shouldn’t criss-cross or come out of their expected alignment (FIG i). If they do, decrease MaxIter (around line 45) in the snap2dural_energy_customized.m file. This can involve a lot of trial and error, but generally, if it doesn't work at default (MaxIter=50), then you should decrease it to \u003c5. You can also check the Tips for Customizing iELVis Code Package.docx file for some help (see Materials).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":375,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":452,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":481,"length":8},{"style":"italic","offset":513,"length":31},{"style":"italic","offset":710,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43miu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9giln","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7uftb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B9BB51F04EE211ED99A8FFD3D7AB3136","height":608,"id":354088,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":2,"offset":5,"style":"bold"},{"length":2,"offset":59,"style":"bold"},{"length":8,"offset":44,"style":"italic"}],"key":"2i5q1","text":"Panel i is a bad snap and requires changing MaxIter. Panel ii is a good snap.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Snap_To_Grid_Fig_C.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k33kbxz37.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k33ibxz37.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/k33jbxz37.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k33hbxz37.webp","width":320}}}}

steps.section: Snapping the Grid to Brain Surface (only applicable for grid/strip (ECoG) electrodes
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ek3hn","text":"Once you have the snapped coordinates, run the next two MATLAB sections which overwrites the input RAS file to have the newly snapped coordinates. This section also makes a backup so you can redo the snap if need be (id##_RAS_bkp.xlsx). Make sure the RAS_coords_new variable (~line 55) has the electrodes in the same order that they were in the original RAS file. For example, if the input RAS has order of electrodes: GR1-64, RAH1-16, RPH1-12, STS1-16, then you should have the output {rasElecName}_coor_snapped in the same order in the RAS_coords_new variable. Plot the newly made snapped RAS and examine it carefully to ensure it is accurate. This can be done by running the first two sections of the imaging code (Step 6) with the newly snapped RAS.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":217,"length":17},{"style":"italic","offset":251,"length":15},{"style":"italic","offset":486,"length":27},{"style":"italic","offset":538,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d0p36","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1uk0j","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C038D9804EE211ED99A8FFD3D7AB3136","height":611,"id":354092,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":6,"style":"bold"},{"length":3,"offset":45,"style":"bold"}],"key":"f288t","text":"Panel i is an un-snapped grid, whereas Panel ii  is snapped","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Snap_To_Grid_Fig_D.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k33qbxz37.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k33nbxz37.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/k33pbxz37.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k33mbxz37.webp","width":453}}}}

steps.section: Multi-Modality Visualization Tool (MMVT) and Electrode Labeling Algorithm (ELA)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"42ime","text":"Multi-Modality Visualization Tool (MMVT) and Electrode Labeling Algorithm (ELA)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":79}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efkv9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ep0u2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e5th4","text":"The Multi-Modality Visualization Tool (MMVT) is an open-source python package that converts the reconstruction output into a Blender (blender.org) file for three-dimensional visualization of electrode locations which can incorporate MRI, FreeSurfer output, RAS mapping, and even evoked potentials into the visualization. We will use the “lite” version of MMVT, which is a stripped-down version, without Blender. Please follow the guide in Appendix VII to set up MMVT-lite. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7qabi","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8m3iu","text":"You will need a FreeSurfer Output for the patient (Step 7.3), and a RAS coordinate sheet (Step 7.4). We recommend keeping them together in a “reconstruction” folder, but it is not absolutely necessary.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eifbo","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cbs9u","text":"Importantly, using underscores in the subject ID will causes this step to fail.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: iEEG BIDS Data Formatting for Data Sharing
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ev7oi","text":"iEEG BIDS formatting of channel labels and file formats","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":55}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cphvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ajd13","text":"A final step for the RAS file is to prepare the RAS channel data following FAIR practices (https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201618) and the standard iEEG BIDS format (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-019-0105-7). For the iEEG BIDS formatting, manual entry to the RAS file for the electrode types (sEEG, grid, strip, or ECoG), electrode manufacturer, per-contact surface area (exposure to the brain), electrode group (e.g., the prefix label in front of electrode number), and the brain hemisphere. These details are recommended standard practice for information per RAS file, and, in our case, we made a copy and named this file:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":91,"length":43},{"key":1,"offset":171,"length":49}],"data":[]},{"key":"35tnb","text":"    “(patient designation)_ElectrodeInfo_RAS.xlsx” ( https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-019-0105-7).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":52,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":53,"length":49}],"data":[]},{"key":"9aakk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"76fag","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"cuhi0","text":"The spreadsheet file along with other files can then be saved into the iEEG BIDS format, which involves following the BIDS file structure. Additional code is included (https://github.com/Center-For-Neurotechnology/Reconstruction-coreg-pipeline/tree/main/Deidentification_BIDSiEEG ) that uses the bids-starter kit code (https://bids-standard.github.io/bids-starter-kit/) and tailors it for this current format. steps.section: Measurements of electrode location relative to brain features
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9tf9l","text":"Measurements of electrode location relative to brain features","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6hvtd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2ekk4","text":"Following electrode localization, there are a number of different measures which could be relevant to further study, including localization relative to grey and white matter, different brain regions using a volumetric approach, contact size, and contact spacing. The organization of the FreeSurfer folders and RAS coordinates allow us to perform automatic calculations of these metrics using the current code. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6vguo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3cl4g","text":"A second type of labelling, electrode volume labelling (EVL), involves mapping electrode locations relative to volumes (as opposed to surfaces like ELA). To do this, we have to export the FreeSurfer parcellations to volumes, which involves using 3DSlicer (https://www.slicer.org/). The steps involve importing files from the surfer folder and then saving the volumes per brain label: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":256,"length":23}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E4DDA246463711EDB54B0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.slicer.org"}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3g4tv","text":"Save the output volumes of the parcellations: save (export) to the selected folder.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"218vr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2k8m","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"dct66","text":"The resultant saved volumes can be used for later processing and mapping of electrode labels.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"124F56204EE511ED99A8FFD3D7AB3136","height":143,"id":354140,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":23,"offset":24}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":80,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"dl0i2","text":"Screenshot of 3DSlicer (https://www.slicer.org/) export of volumes to .stl files","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[{"data":{"guid":"0351D934509611EDB8B00A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.slicer.org"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"VolumeSaving3DSlicer_3.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k348bxz37.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k346bxz37.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/k347bxz37.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k345bxz37.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.section: Measurements of electrode location relative to brain features
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"518b","text":"The next step involves involves running already created MATLAB code that uses the FreeSurfer, RAS, and MMVT file output structure to perform different calculations regarding electrode location, label electrodes based on the DKT40 atlas (https://mindboggle.info/data.html) or other selected brain atlas maps and produce output that matches the iEEG BIDS formatting. The code itself (Measurements_and_Labelling_RAS.m) performs the calculations and is dependent on the FreeSurfer and MMVT file structures and folder organization but, once organized, can just be run after pointing the script toward the correct participant designation. The code produces a spreadsheet (below), which includes further different measures and brain localization information. The code currently works with MATLAB 2020b onward though several of the functions can be run with older versions of MATLAB.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":237,"length":33}],"data":[]},{"key":"1833n","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"hbtt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"DA9F2008509511EDB8B00A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://mindboggle.info/data.html"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"84501270509611EDB5A4A104DEFC5DE7","height":777,"id":354144,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":121,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"i9e4","text":"Output spreadsheet regarding measures of each contact relative to anatomical features as well as features of each contact","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"OutputSpreadsheet.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k35cbynsf.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k35abynsf.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/k35bbynsf.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k349bynsf.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.section: De-Identifying MRIs and CTs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8ud07","text":"To remove identifying features, in addition to de-identifying the DICOM headers or re-saving the data as NIFTI files and removing the identifying header information, with instructions and approaches to do so outlined by various other sites (https://www.fieldtriptoolbox.org/). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":241,"length":33}],"data":[]},{"key":"4t6gv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8rpbj","text":"An additional step is to remove facial features in the MRI and CT images and save the images into a format that can be read by steps in the pipeline such as FreeSurfer. This step involves using the Fieldtrip software and the functions ft_read_mri, ft_defacevolume, and the ft_write_mri functions. The procedure involves setting the path to the downloaded Fieldtrip code (see instructions on the Fieldtrip website) followed by running the functions pointing to the files and directories where the preoperative and postoperative images were located. The ft_defacevolumefunction opens up a graphic user interface (GUI) window that allows you to change he rotation and shape of the yellow box by entering numbers into the lower right corner of the box. Once you are satisfied the box covers the facial features for the scan, close the window which will result in saved anonymized MRI which can be saved using the ft_write_mri function.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d4r7m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9up5q","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"1t7em","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"A551C608463A11EDB54B0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.fieldtriptoolbox.org"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"5A11B2A04EE511ED99A8FFD3D7AB3136","height":469,"id":354148,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":33,"offset":42}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":42,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":1,"offset":75,"style":"bold"}],"key":"afiri","text":"Manual defacing pipeline using Fieldtrip (https://www.fieldtriptoolbox.org/)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[{"data":{"guid":"66F0FCCF509711EDB8B00A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.fieldtriptoolbox.org"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Defacing.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k35gbxz37.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k35ebxz37.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/k35fbxz37.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k35dbxz37.webp","width":550}}}}
